author: treyzania
content: so attesting a block with an invalid execution payload isn't slashable either?

author: potuz
content: It isn't and hacking clients to not use and EE and attest to anything and propose with MEV boost may be a winning strategy until proof of execution is a thing.

author: m.kalinin
content: Proof of execution is challenging in the context of consensus splits as EVM traces obtained from block execution may be different to a party that is on the other side of the split

author: potuz
content: Well but the part that retroactively we can slash an actor that signed on an INVALID block is deterministic

author: m.kalinin
content: Ideally, we should only slash if a validator can't prove that it has executed a payload before attesting to a block. Probably, it could be prove execution of 3 random transactions from a block and if 2 of them are proved then the challenge is considered won by attester

author: potuz
content: The simplest engineering I can think of is including in VALID blocks a new type of slashing where the signed attestation is included as well as the INVALID block attested to, or a proof that such an INVALID block existed

author: m.kalinin
content: But do we want to slash for attesting to INVALID block? I am not sure that such misbehaviour should be punished that severe

author: potuz
content: Yes I do, the most obvious reasons for such behaviors are an optimistic node not caring or a node that doesn't execute. Then a bug in the EE

author: m.kalinin
content: If you're in optimistic mode you won't be able to generate a proof of execution as your EL doesn't have a state to execute a payload. Attesting to INVALID payload in this case should be slashable by the definition of proof of execution. While attesting to INVALID payload because of EE bug is not that obvious, validator that has honestly executed a block may be slashed for no reason in this case

author: potuz
content:
There's no way to distinguish between 1)I attested to this INVALID block because I didn't care validating it
2) I validated it, was INVALID and still didn't care
3) validated it, my EE told me it was valid and it wasn't, there was a bug.

author: ajsutton
content: I think slashing validators based on a chain split bug in the EE could be problematic.  Ideally though we could apply a penalty rather than a full slashing. That would be enough to ensure you lose money if you attest without validating but not be so harsh.  But then it's a bunch more complexity and potentially has scaling issues - imagine a node running thousands of validators that has an EE bug, we'd have thousands of these penalties to include and process every epoch. With slashing they'd be exited so we'd have thousands of slashings but then they'd stop.

author: potuz
content: I tend to agree, I think this goes into my bucket of "things that are not an issue until they are so let's not fix a problem that does not exists"... but at the same time are in the bucket of "If I weren't withdrawing my 2 validators as soon as I can  I'd hack my node to not run geth anymore"

author: sky.cactus
content: If we can reliably tell when someone isn't executing blocks, could we just force exit them and nothing else?  Is that punishment enough?
